M. Deshpande, S. S. Divekar, B. M. Bhanage and R. V. Chaudhari** Chemical Engineering Division, National Chemical Laboratory, Pune 411 008 (India) (Received April 8, 1992; accepted July 6, 1992) The hydroformylation reaction is important industrially for the manufacture of alcohols and aldehydes from olefins [ 1 ]. The stoichiometric reaction is: R-CH=CH2 + CO + HZ-1 R-CH2-CH2-CHO n-aldehyde rR-CH-CHO ICH3 iso-aldehyde The types of catalysts used and the selectivity behaviour have been described in detail by Cornils [ 1 ]. The most active and selective catalyst for the hydroformylation of olefins is Wilkinson's complex, HRh(CO)(PPh3)3. The kinetics of the hydroformylation of olefins using this catalyst has been studied previously [2-4], and one of the important observations was the inhibition of reaction rates at higher concentrations of olefins and CO. In this letter we report some interesting results on the effect of solvent on the hydroformylation of 1-hexene, particularly the effect of the olefin concentration. The effect of 1-hexene concentration on the activity of HRh(CO)(PPh3)3 catalyzed hydroformylation has been studied in various solvents. It was observed that the rate was inhibited at higher concentrations of 1-hexene in all of the solvents. However, the maximum rate was found to be strongly dependent on the type of solvent used. The probable reasons for such behaviour are discussed. *NCL Communication No. 5151. "Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/92/$05.00 0 1992 - Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved L14 Experimental The equipment and the experimental procedure were the same as described in our earlier work [ 2 ] . Results and discussion The hydroformylation reactions were carried out at a catalyst concentration of 1.0 X 10-3 kmol m-3 and at p(CO) -p(HZ) -1.034 MPa with the objective of understanding the effect of olefin concentration in different solvent systems. The results are presented in FIg. 1. It was observed that the rate passed through maxima for all the solvents. Interestingly, the position of the maximum corresponding to the optimum rate of hydroformylation with olefin concentration was found to shift, depending on the solvent. In ethanol as solvent, the maximum rate was observed at an olefin concentration of 0.35 kmol m-3 (olefin-to-catalyst ratio= 350). In the case of benzene as solvent, the maximum rate occurred at an olefin concentration of 5.0 kmol m-3 (olefin-to-catalyst ratio= 5000). The maxima in the cases of n-heptanol and toluene were found to lie within these two extremes, viz. at olefin concentrations of 1.35 kmol m-3 (olefin-to-catalyst ratio= 1350) and 3.3 kmol m-3 (olefin-to-catalyst ratio = 3300), respectively. Thus the maximum in the rates was found to be strongly solvent dependent. The n/ iso ratio was, however, not significantly affected by changes in the 1-hexene concentration for each solvent. Solvent-coordinated species when solvents such as ethanol and benzene are used have been reported earlier [5]. Since the inhibition is observed to s h 5 U m . 4 o_ X 3 N U 2 W W 1 0 J i ' i L i 0 1 2 3 4 5 CONCENTRATION OF I-HEXENExIO;mol/CfI13 SOLVENTS BENZENE * TOLUENE 1 ETHANOL a n-HEPTANOL i i I 6 7 B Fig. 1. Mechanism of hyaroformylation using HRh(CO)(PPh3)3. be mainly as a function of the olefin-to-catalyst ratios, it is unlikely that coordination with the solvent plays an active role in inhibiting the rate at higher olefin concentrations. When pure 1-hexene was used as the medium, the rate was strongly inhibited, indicating that olefin interaction with the catalyst is a likely reason for inhibition. Wilkinson and co-workers [ 5 ] have proposed a catalytic cycle for the hydroformylation reaction, shown in Fig. 2. This mechanism consists of two routes, viz. associative and dissociative mechanisms. In both of these routes the oxidative addition of hydrogen to the acyl complex (step 6 in Fig. 2) is rate controlling. It was reported [6, 7] that formation of alkyl olefinic Rh species occurs in the hydroformylation of ethylene using Rh4(CO)12 catalyst, as shown below. C2H5Rh(CO)3 + C,H4 -~ C2H5Rh(CO)3(C2H4) S1 S2 C2H5Rh(CO)3(C2H4) -'-' C2H5CORh(CO)2(C2H4) S3 L16 10 E 8 o Pco = P,a = 2758 MPa 1 PLO = P,,= = 1 034 MPa o0 x 6 z O N U 4 w w O w 2 H a O 1 2 3 4 5 CONCENTRATION OF 1-HEXENEx103,mo1/cm3 Fig. 3. Effect of olefin concentration on the rate of reaction. Reaction conditions: temp. 50 C; [catalyst]= 1.00 X 10-a mol cm-3. This type of mechanism has been proposed for the formation of dialkyl ketones. It is likely that similar species may form in the hydroformylation of 1-hexene using HRh(CO)(PPh3)3 as catalyst. Such a species can be formed by attack of 1-hexene on species E and F, as shown in Fig. 2. This will lead to a reduction in the concentration of active catalyst available for the reaction, causing a reduction in the reaction rate. The formation of such inhibited species will occur to different extents in different solvents. This will result in a shift in the rate maximum with type of solvent. King et al. [6] have also reported that these species (S2 and S3) are formed at lower CO partial pressures. To observe the exact nature of the rate inhibition in the hydroformylation of 1-hexene, a few reactions were run to check indirectly the formation of inhibited species. Reactions were performed in ethanol solvent under various conditions, and the results are shown in Fig. 3. The increase in the rate with total pressure at low olefin concentrations was also marginal. It was observed that at low partial pressures of CO and H2, the inhibition of the rate at higher olefin concentrations was severe. At high pressures of CO and Hz, however, the inhibition of the rate at corresponding olefin concentrations was negligible. These observations show that higher partial pressures of CO can prevent the formation of inhibiting species, as suggested by King et al. [6]. Conclusions The maximum in the rate with olefin concentration was found to be highly dependent on the solvent used. The shift in the maximum rate with olefin was probably due to formation of inhibiting species and their stabilization in the solvent. Although some contribution to this phenomenon by solvent coordination cannot be ruled out, it appears unlikely that this could be a major factor in causing inhibition of the rate with 1-hexene concentration. L17 Further investigations on these systems are necessary for identification of the inhibiting species. References 1 B. Comics, in J.
